newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kohl defends Waigel after German tax feud.
newsitem.headline: Kohl defends Waigel after German tax feud.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Monday defended his finance minister and said the centre-right Bonn coalition, deeply split last week in a tax dispute, must stick together and win the 1998 election.

Kohl told fellow Christian Democrats (CDU) at the start of their annual congress that Theo Waigel, chairman of the allied Christian Social Union (CSU), was a dependable finance minister who faced enormous tasks.
The 14-year coalition of CDU, CSU and the liberal Free Democrats (FDP) could use some improvements, he admitted, but staying together was the only way for them to win re-election.

Kohl's coalition came dangerously close to collapse last week when Waigel and the FDP battled over a possible petrol tax increase to ensure the 1997 budget deficit was low enough to qualify for Europe's single currency.

The coalition agreed on Friday to delay a planned cut in the hated solidarity surcharge, a tax to help rebuild the ex-communist east, but coalition members continued to squabble over the weekend about when taxes could next be cut.
Kohl demonstratively thanked Waigel and said: "He is the target of many attacks, but he is a dependable man."
The coalition had been through good and bad times in the past 14 years, added Kohl, who on October 31 will set a record as Germany's longest-serving postwar chancellor.
"It is also true that this or that could be improved in our coalition, despite all its successes," he said. "Our goal is clear -- we want to continue this coalition of the centre beyond 1998."

The two-day CDU congress in Hanover was due to discuss plans for tax reform, introduce a quota for women office holders and hold elections for the party leadership. Kohl, CDU chairman for the past 23 years, has no challenger.
